summary: This research investigates the evolutionary relationship between brain size and body size in birds, revealing that while birds can have brain sizes comparable to primates, the factors and patterns driving avian brain evolution are not fully understood. The study finds that significant increases in relative brain size did not occur during the miniaturization and flight evolution of theropods. Instead, theropods and early birds exhibited less correlation between brain and body sizes, allowing for rapid evolutionary changes. Following the Cretaceous-Paleogene mass extinction, several bird lineages experienced increases in relative brain size due to reductions in body size. Notably, parrots and corvids, which have the largest brains among birds, achieved this through different evolutionary strategies: parrots reduced body size while corvids increased both body and brain sizes. These findings suggest that early adaptations in brain size may have set the stage for future evolutionary stability and selection in birds.
